Translated by Zhi Qian, an UpÄsaka of the State of Yuezhi in Wu, with the courtesy name Gongming
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, if they fall into the animal realm,
The various good dharmas they practice, the non-Buddhists cannot attain.
As I have heard before:

In the past, the bodhisattva was once a rabbit. Due to the remaining causes and conditions of his past karma, although he received a rabbit's body, he was good at speaking the human language, and his words were always sincere without falsehood;
He accomplished wisdom and was free from anger, and was the foremost among humans and gods;
His mind was permeated with compassion, and he was gentle and kind, able to completely eliminate all demonic causes and conditions;
His words and actions were consistent, and he was truthful and without flattery, and the thought of killing was forever gone;
He abided unmoving like Mount Sumeru, and was the leader of countless rabbits, always saying to the rabbits:
Do you not know that you will fall into the evil paths?
This body is a source of suffering.

The evil paths refer to the hells, animal realms, hungry ghost realms, and asura realms. These are called the evil paths. You should now listen attentively with a focused mind. The causes and conditions for falling into the evil paths are the ten evil deeds.
In the past, I have heard the sages make distinctions and explanations, and I have also contemplated them. I will now briefly explain them for you.
The root of the four dharmas has many faults, namely greed, anger, delusion, and arrogance.ğŸ”½Those who commit the ten evil deeds out of a greedy mind fall into the hungry ghost realm;
those who commit the ten evil deeds out of an angry mind fall into the animal realm;
those who commit the ten evil deeds out of a deluded mind fall into the hells;
those who commit the ten evil deeds out of an arrogant mind fall into the asura realm. Because of these four dharmas, wherever one goes, one will always suffer.

You should observe that in the hells there is fierce fire blazing, sharp knives cutting and peeling, always being eaten by dogs, iron spears and crows pecking at their eyes, ash rivers destroying the body like fine dust, and being smashed by hammers, sharp axes and swords cutting off their hands and feet, cold evil winds blowing and folding their bodies.
Two mountains collide and the body is in between.

You should know that even if I were to explain for a hundred thousand lifetimes, I could not finish describing the various sufferings of the beings in the hells. There are such various sufferings in the hells.
You should now listen to the various sufferings of the hungry ghosts, namely, being tormented by hunger and thirst, the body withered, for countless years not having heard the name of drink or water.

Even if they seek filth, they cannot find it. Their hair grows long and sharp, entwining their bodies, causing the limbs and joints of their bodies to burn with fire. From afar, they see what appears to be water, but it becomes a pit of fire. Driven by hunger and thirst, they approach what seems to be filth, but there are evil ghosts and spirits wielding knives and sticks to firmly block them. Now that I speak of this matter, it makes my heart tremble with fear and dread even more.

As for the asuras, although they experience the five desires, they are no different from the gods. However, they are arrogant and self-important, lacking humility. They stay far away from good spiritual friends, do not believe in the Three Jewels, and are also not protected by good companions. In the world, they give rise to inverted thoughts. Although they see the buddhas, their minds lack reverence and faith. They always give rise to evil thoughts towards the gods above and fixate on seeking the faults of the gods.ğŸ”½You should know that the fetter of arrogance has many faults and brings no benefit.
Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Therefore, sentient beings do not attain the fruit of the Way, all because of the rampant arrogance of this, criticizing and blaming oneself and others, slandering and reviling. Because of arrogance, sentient beings in the world increase their wrong views, and because of wrong views, they slander the Three Jewels.
Because of slandering the Three Jewels, they receive the body of an asura. The various sufferings received in the asura realm, if one were to speak of them all, would be inexhaustible.

Because of the causes and conditions of foolishness, one falls into the animal realm and receives many sufferings. One receives various forms, eats various foods, speaks various languages, and moves and abides differently.

Without feet, with two feet, with four feet, with many feet, in water, on land, and in the sky, cows, sheep, camels, donkeys, pigs, chickens, dogs, flying birds, running beasts, and so forth - such groups are always covered by foolishness.

They always dwell in darkness and ignorance, lacking wisdom. They give rise to thoughts of killing each other, fearing each other like enemies. They are always killed by hunters and butchers, and also devoured by countless ferocious beasts such as lions, tigers, wolves, and dogs.

They always fall into pits, ditches, and traps, and when born, they carry heavy burdens and are skinned and slaughtered when dead. They pull plows and carts, hooked by iron hooks, and are bound and restrained.
They always suffer from hunger and thirst, with dry mouths and parched tongues. Even if they have needs, they cannot express themselves.

Young and orphaned, far from their parents, with countless water and grass, they are never satisfied. The evil retributions of animals are seen in the world. Therefore, I will now briefly explain them for you all.

Because of my previous evil karma, I have received this rabbit body, always eating water and grass, and constantly in fear. Therefore, you should cultivate good dharmas. Due to the causes and conditions of good dharmas, one is born among humans and gods. Although there are various sufferings and afflictions among humans that are worse than in the heavens, one should still make a vow to be born among humans.
It is like the law of officials creating earthen pits for criminals, which have three layers:
The most severely punished person is placed in the lowest layer;
The person with a medium crime is placed in the middle layer;
The person with the lightest crime is placed in the upper layer.

Those who commit evil deeds are also like this. The most severely evil person falls into hell; The person with a medium level of evil receives the body of an animal; The person with the lightest level of evil is born among hungry ghosts.
Far away from these three levels of evil, one is born among humans. Having been born among humans, one practices good and evil;
Those who practice the highest good enter nirvana as if it were their own house.
At that time, the rabbit king always proclaimed such wonderful and good words for the rabbits.
At that time, there was a brahmin who became disgusted with the world and left home to study the practices of a sage. He did not harm sentient beings, was free from desires and attachments;
he spoke with a gentle face and his body was free from coarseness, drinking water, eating fruits and various medicinal herbs;
with few desires and contentment, he practiced the way of tranquility, letting his hair and nails grow as the characteristics of a pure practitioner.
At that time, the sage suddenly heard from afar the rabbit king speaking the Dharma for the rabbits one time. Having heard it, he felt remorse and said this:
Although I have now been born among humans, I am foolish and ignorant, not as good as this rabbit. Born among rabbits, yet understanding good dharmas.
It is like the sunlight obscuring the moonlight. I am also like this.

Although born among humans, they are obstructed by those animals. Although they are animals, they may be the vanguard of the true Dharma, or Brahma kings, or MaheÅ›vara. I now listen to the Dharma they speak, my mind subdued and gentle, like a person entering cool water when hot.
Alas, O lion!
You commit many evil deeds and receive this animal body. How can you kill such a rabbit?

Such a rabbit is purely good. Although its form is like this, it is able to practice the Dharma of sages and immortals. Although born as an animal, it is able to proclaim the characteristics of good and evil.
From the beginning, I have had no one to consult and respect. Now that I have encountered this, it is extremely good and immeasurable.
At that time, the sage immediately rose, put his palms together, and went to where the rabbit was.
Having arrived where the rabbit was, he sat to one side, put his palms together facing the rabbit, and said these words:
You are the body of the true Dharma, you will not receive the body of a rabbit, all the definitely pure good dharmas, please explain them in detail for me.

The cultivation I have practiced, growing my beard and hair, wearing grass clothes, and eating fruits, I now truly dislike them. It is like drilling ice to seek butter, which is truly difficult to obtain, I am also like this.
Throughout my life, growing my hair, wearing grass clothes, and eating fruits, although I practice austerities, it is difficult to attain the true Dharma.

Although I have now been born among humans and received a human body, I stay far away from good teachers and practice evil dharmas, like the seven-leaf flower that can only be admired from afar and cannot be approached, I am also like this.
Practicing evil dharmas, a wise person will look at it from afar and never get close to it, you are truly a Brahma King who temporarily receives the body of a rabbit.
The rabbit replied at that time:
Great Brahmin!
If what I say pleases your mind, it is very unlikable.
Why is it so?
I have long been free from the bonds of stinginess.
In the past, I made the resolve to enter nirvana, but only for the sake of sentient beings did I remain in samsara for a long time.
When the brahmin heard these words, he was overjoyed:
You are a great being who can remain here for a long time for the sake of sentient beings.
He then followed [the rabbit] for many years, drinking water and eating fruit no differently than the rabbit.

At that time, many people in the world engaged in evil ways. For this reason, the heavens became hot and dry, causing the grass, trees, flowers, and fruits to wither and not grow. The waters of the oceans, ponds, wells, and springs dried up. All the forests, trees, herbs, and grasses on the land, as well as the people and their harvests, were completely exhausted.
At that time, the brahmin, hungry, destitute, and suffering, spoke to the rabbit with a gentle expression, saying:
I now wish to leave. I hope you will not blame me.
When the rabbit heard this, he thought to himself:
This great sage does not enjoy this place, so he wants to part ways with us.
He then asked:
What is wrong with this place? What offense has been committed?

Great sage, consider that your body is wearing such coarse grass robes, causing your mind to be sorrowful and uneasy, like a brahmin entering a prostitute's house, which is very against the family rules.
The brahmin said:
What you have said truly enters my mind. This place is pure and truly has no faults. The rabbits themselves practice and do not offend each other.
But I am of little merit and am suffering from lack of food and drink, so I am reluctantly about to part ways with you.

You should now consider that all sentient beings, without exception, rely on food to sustain this body. The well-spoken essential teachings you have given, although I am now leaving far away, I will always keep them in my heart and not forget them.
You should also know that my mind is without compassion, and it is because of defiled food that I am parting from you.
The rabbit replied:
What you are doing is a small matter, why do you want to leave me?
The brÄhman said:
I have been drinking water for many days, I fear my life will not be complete, therefore I want to leave you.
Having heard this, the rabbit thought:
Excellent!
This brÄhman is able to drink water for the sake of the Dharma for many days.
He then said:
If you leave, I will have no such field of merit. I only wish that you, sir, will clearly accept my invitation.
Although I know that the bodhisattva has no discrimination in his mind regarding fields of merit, still the merit of giving to extremely hungry and thirsty beings is the greatest;
Although I know that the two eyes are what I always protect, still I should first save the place of suffering.
You are now my close good friend, whom I respect and have great merit. Therefore, I now wish to make a small offering.
You should now know that there are four kinds of people, and there are also four kinds of giving:
The inferior, the inferior-medium, the wise, and the wise-medium.
What is meant by the inferior?
When giving, they give with the intention of seeking various existences;
The inferior-medium:
They practice giving out of fear;
The wise:
They practice giving with a respectful mind;
The wise-medium:
They practice giving with a mind of great compassion.
I now practice one of these four kinds of giving. I only wish that you will definitely accept my invitation tomorrow morning.
At that time, the brÄhman had this thought:
What did this rabbit see today?
Did he see a dead deer?
Or a dead rabbit?
His mind was delighted and he kindled the fire and chanted spells.
That night the rabbit collected a lot of dry firewood and told the other rabbits:
You should know that this brÄhman now wishes to abandon me and go far away to another's house. I am very sad and my body is trembling.

The worldly dharmas are like this, impermanent and separate, false and unreal, like an illusion, coming together and separating, like the autumn rains. The conditioned dharmas have immeasurable faults like this. The practices are like a dream, like the heat of summer. When the life of sentient beings ends, there is no returning.
You now know that the worldly dharmas are like this, yet you are unable to be apart from them. Therefore, you must diligently destroy the three existences!
At that time, the king of rabbits did not sleep all night, teaching the rabbit-herd like this.
When the night was over and it was dawn, he blew on the fire by the firewood pile. After the fire was lit, he said to the brÄhman:
Yesterday I invited you, wishing to make a small offering. It is now fully prepared. Please eat it.
Why is it so?
The wise gather wealth with the intention of giving it away. The recipient, out of compassion, must accept and use it.
If an ordinary person accumulates much wealth and gives it to others, this is not difficult.
I am now poor, and giving is difficult. I only wish you will have pity and definitely accept it;
I now sincerely and purely request, I only wish you will definitely accept it without doubt.
Having said this, he further comforted himself:
I now give up my own body for the sake of bringing others peace and happiness, not cherishing it as much as a single hair.
I wish that the fruits of this merit will enable all sentient beings to realize supreme wisdom.
Having comforted himself, he threw himself into the fire pit.
At that time, the brahmin, seeing this, was shocked and his hair stood on end. He then pulled him out from the fire.
The impermanent life then came to an end. He carefully observed and felt dizzy. He held him on his lap, kissed him, and said:
The one who loves the Dharma, the great sage of compassion, the ferryman who tames!
For the sake of benefiting beings, you gave up your body and life. Where have you gone now?
I now respectfully pay homage to you, the lord to whom I go for refuge.
I have been living in this mountain, letting my hair grow long as a heavy burden. Although many years have passed, I have not benefited anyone.
I vow from now on to always bear you on my head. May your merit and virtue be fully accomplished;
May I always be your disciple in the future.

Having said this, he took the rabbit's body back and placed it on the ground. He bowed his head in reverence, then picked it up again as if it were a newborn baby, and together with the dead rabbit, they jumped into the fire pit.
At that time, the god Åšakra, knowing what had happened, made extensive offerings and collected the bones to build a stÅ«pa.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices such as this, the perfection of morality, and does not deceive the world.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the great perfections,
I will never give rise to an evil mind.
I have heard this before:
In the past, the Bodhisattva fell into the animal realm and became a deer.
The two sides of his body were golden in color, his back was like lapis lazuli, and the rest of his body was a mixture of various colors difficult to name.
His hooves were like malachite, his antlers like cinnabar, and his body was adorned like a treasure trove of the seven jewels.
He always benefited all beings, possessing and accomplishing all wholesome dharmas;
The radiance of his body was like the rising sun. The devas revered him and gave him the name Golden-Colored Deer.

He was the leader of countless deer. This deer king practiced great compassion, was diligent and wise, and was fully endowed with courage. He was able to understand human speech in order to tame beings and manifested the body of a deer.

At that time, the king of deer was roaming in the Himalayas, where there were many thickets, flowers, fruits, streams, and bathing pools. If the birds and beasts had mutual hatred and thoughts of robbery and harm, due to the power of the bodhisattva's virtue and virtue, they all disappeared without remainder.
In a secluded place, he always taught the deer to stay away from all evils and practice good dharmas. He told the deer:
You should listen!
Among all practices, you should observe even the slightest evil as if it were poisonous food. You should not accept such slight evil.
You should observe even the slightest good as if it were a close friend, and always be close to it, diligently upholding it.

You deer, because of your body, speech, and mind committing evil deeds, you have fallen into the animal realm and are unable to practice any good dharmas. Because of being covered by ignorance, you have received this animal body, and for countless eons it is difficult to attain liberation from birth and death.
Those who wish to experience happiness must take the true Dharma as their foundation. The true Dharma can protect sentient beings from falling into evil destinies.

It serves as a bridge for those who wish to cross the sea of afflictions and suffering. Just as a person in a dangerous place must rely on a staff, or just as holding a torch allows one to see various objects,
practicing the true Dharma is also like this. The true Dharma is the most intimate and indestructible, and can show sentient beings the unsurpassed great path.

This is able to bring about happiness. Having heard this Dharma, it can cause the mind to be joyful. The mind that continuously practices this Dharma is fearless. This Dharma is able to eliminate all evils.

It is like a good medicine that cures various illnesses. For these reasons, one should always remember it and not let it be forgotten. If it is forgotten, this life will be wasted. All worlds are false and deceptive.
Only the Dharma of giving, patience, shame, and wisdom is true. If one is able to practice such dharmas, then this is called being replete with the true Dharma.
For the birds and beasts, he always expounded this Dharma, causing those who listened to be free from lustful thoughts.
At that time, it was just like the sages being far removed from evil and not adding to harm.

Later, he was with a herd of deer staying by a river, the water of which was vast and deep without a bottom, violently swelling and rushing with many things floating and sinking, destroying the mountain banks and blowing down large trees, with all the birds and beasts not daring to approach.

At that time, there was a person being carried away by the water, terrified and confused not knowing where to go, with his physical strength gradually diminishing and his remaining life almost gone, he raised his voice and cried out loudly:
Celestial spirits, earth spirits, who has compassion and can see to save and deliver?ğŸ”½Alas!
Alas!
Now I am separated from my family and friends, and today I am exhausted and distressed. Who can I take refuge in?
I have heard that in the world there is a deer who has practiced the Dharma of sages and has great compassion. He alone will be able to deeply see and rescue me.
At that time, the king of deer heard these words in front of the herd of deer, and immediately looked in surprise at who was suffering, and said these words:
Having heard this, my heart is distressed, just like the suffering of those who are suffering, no different.
He then told the deer:
You should go wherever you wish and disperse on your own. I want to look for a flat place to drink water to my heart's content and satisfy my thirst.
When the deer heard this, they immediately scattered in all directions.
The king of deer then followed the sound and sought, and saw a person being carried away by the water, further struck by wood and stones, and suffering much distress.
Having seen this, the king of deer immediately had this thought:
The water is rushing swiftly, even a large fish would not be able to cross it. My body is small and my strength is also weak, how can I possibly save this person?
It would be better if I die together with him. I really cannot bear to see him suffer alone.
He further thought:
If he were on land and troubled by an elephant, I could find a way to rescue him. But now he is drifting in the swift water, how can I save him?
If I enter the water and am unable to save him, everyone will hear about it and laugh at me. Knowing I cannot do it, why would I enter the water?
Although I now have a compassionate heart, my physical strength is weak and I fear I cannot accomplish it.
I must now redouble my efforts and go to save him without rest.
He then said:
You should not be afraid now. I will enter the water like grass and trees. Even if my body is destroyed, I will definitely save you.
At that time, the deer king jumped into the river to where the man was, and told the drowning man to sit on its back.

The drowning man sat down in peace and without worry, just like a person sitting comfortably on a bed. In the river there were many trees and rocks that bumped into each other, causing pain to the body.
At that time, the deer king carried the drowning man until death, never letting go, and only then was it able to get out to the other shore.
At that time, the drowning man was immediately rescued and safely emerged. He then said to the deer king:
The body that was raised by my parents has already perished. Now this life and body truly belong to you.
Although you are a deer king, our lives are connected. Whatever you command, please tell me.
At that time, the deer king said to the man:
Listen now, I do not seek merit or reward from you, nor do I have any thought of being arrogant. I now do not begrudge such a life and body, but only wish to benefit others.
You should know that I, having received a beast's body, always dwell in the forest, freely seeking water and grass as I please. Although I do not encroach upon the villages of residents,
It is my fault that there are many resentful enemies, and I am also afraid of lions, tigers, wolves, and other vicious beasts, as well as hunters. I have nowhere to turn for refuge or protection.

Although my deer body has various subtle colors, no one in the world has seen it. Only you have seen it as I rescued you. In the past, I made a vow that if I saw suffering and distress, I would definitely deliver them. Even if a person has the power to see suffering and not rescue, one should know that such a person will have no reward, just as if one does not plant seeds, one will not harvest fruits.
If you think of me, you should well control your mouth, know kindness and repay kindness, and be praised by the sages;

Those who do not know kindness will have a bad reputation in the present world that spreads to the outside, and will also be scolded by the wise. In the future, they will suffer many evil retributions.

A person who knows kindness is at ease in both worlds. Without the conditions of giving, one attains freedom. Without cultivating much learning, one possesses great wisdom. Although without bathing in water, one is pure and without defilements. Free from all incense fumigation, one attains the unsurpassed fragrance. Free from all necklaces, one attains true adornment. Far from relying on others, one attains self-protection. Although without swords and staves, no one will encroach upon one.

You should know that the merits attained by a person who knows kindness are inexhaustible. The faults attained by a person who does not know kindness are also immeasurable. Therefore, you should now well control your mouth.
At that time, the drowning person, having heard these words, was filled with a mixture of sadness and joy, tears streaming down his face. He then bowed to the feet of the deer and said:

You always expound the Dharma to show sentient beings the right path to nirvana. You are like a good doctor who eliminates the mental fever and suffering of sentient beings. You are the most compassionate father in the world. You are venerable, you are a guide. I truly enjoy following you. I receive your teachings morning and evening and do not wish to be apart from you for even a moment. If I must do evil and am not up to the task,
if I now leave, although I will have a physical body, I will be far apart from you. But my mind will not dare to give rise to the thought of separation.
Having said this, he immediately set out on the road.
The deer king looked into the distance, and when he could no longer see him, he returned to the herd of deer.

At that time, the drowning man, having returned home, forgot his gratitude and betrayed his righteousness. He destroyed the torch of the Dharma and naturally his mind. He destroyed the Dharma tree and planted a forest of poison. His mind became an evil vessel, filled with the poison of resentment. For the sake of present-life benefits, he went to the king and said to him:
Great King, you should know that I recently entered the mountains and saw a deer with a body color as exquisite as a string of seven treasures, leading the herd of deer.
Just like the full moon among the stars, its fur is multicolored and suitable for covering a royal carriage. I know the place where this deer roams and stays.
When the king heard this, he was startled and delighted, saying:
You show me the place and I will go myself to capture it.
The drowning man said to the king:
I respectfully follow your instructions.
The king then prepared his chariot and ordered him to lead the way, with a thousand carriages and ten thousand cavalry following behind.
At that time, the deer king was among the herd, exhausted and asleep.
At that time, there were many birds in the sky who saw the king's troops and horses and said to each other:
This king must be coming for the golden deer.
At that time, a crow went to where the deer was and pecked at the deer king's ears. The deer king was startled and woke up, thinking in his mind:
Why did this crow come to see me? From ancient times, flocks of crows have always circled around without daring to approach. Why did it touch my body today?
The deer then stood up and looked into the distance at the king's army gathering from all directions, already coming close. He thought again:
The crows are truly without fault. It is like a person who is respected and falls down, pulling with their hands. How could that be a fault?
He thought again:
These sentient beings have no compassionate mind. In the world, lions, tigers, and wolves are always my enemies. Hearing me speak the Dharma, the hostile mind immediately ceases.

This person has no reason to be born among humans, forgetting kindness and betraying righteousness, and instead gives rise to poison and harm towards me. It is like a wonderful fragrant flower placed on a corpse, immediately detestable, and people do not like to see it.
This person is also like this. For the sake of a little happiness in the present world, he abandons the immeasurable happy rewards of the future.
At that time, the king of deer said to the deer, Do not worry. The reason the king came here is precisely for my sake, not for yours.
Although I can now escape far away and also destroy that army, I must go to the king and give up my life. If I do this, you will scatter in all directions and even lose your lives.
Therefore, for your sake, I will go to the king. Just follow behind me and do not be afraid. I will make you all safe and without trouble.
You should know that if I give rise to the intention to enter nirvana, I can attain it. The reason I do not attain it is precisely for your sake.
Even if I lose my life when I reach the king, as long as I make you all safe and sound, I will have no regrets.
Having said this, he went to the king and the drowning man saw him. He immediately pointed to the king and said:
This is the deer king you spoke of.
Having said this, his two hands fell to the ground.
When the king saw this, he immediately dismounted, his heart trembling and his hair standing on end, and said:
Why are your hands cut off like this?
He then abandoned his sword and staff and went alone to where the deer was.
When the deer saw the king, his heart was sorrowful. The king thought:
Although he has the body of a beast, he is not really a deer. He is King Virtuous and Courageous.
At that time, the king of deer said to the king:
Great king, for what reason did you abandon your sword and staff, your body sweating as if in fear?
If you are afraid of me, I am cultivating kindness and will never harm you. It is impossible for the moon to give birth to fire.
When the king heard this, he felt at ease and said to the deer king:
Why did this man fall to the ground with both hands?
Yet as you said before, you can give us all fearlessness.
How is it that this man just points to you and receives such a karmic retribution?
You said before that you can give sentient beings fearlessness.
How is it that you have caused this man to be like this?
If you say you do not give, then the entire world will be burned by fire.
At that time, the deer king again said to the king:

It is like a person who commits a serious crime against the state and offends a pure bhiká¹£u free from disputes. Such a person will receive a grave and heavy crime. One who does not know gratitude will also receive a grave and heavy crime in the same way.
King, you should know that this man created it himself and will receive the retribution himself. It is not my cause and condition.
The king then asked:
I only wish you would explain it in detail. I enjoy listening to it.
The deer king replied:
Please ask him yourself, Your Majesty, I have nothing to add.
The king then asked the man:
Why are your two hands on the ground now?
At that time, the drowning man then explained the whole story to the king. After the king heard it, he said:
Since you did this, how can you not receive retribution?

If someone in distress relies on others, even for a single thought, one should repay their kindness, let alone for a long time receiving such heavy kindness, yet being unable to repay it but instead giving rise to treacherous harm. How could one not receive such retribution?
It is like a person resting under a cool tree in the heat. Such a person should not even damage a single leaf of the tree. Being mindful of kindness is also like this.
At that time, the king of the country again knelt for a long time with palms joined and said:
From today onwards, I will always take refuge in you.
The deer king replied:
If you can really do that, I will respectfully accept your offer.
The king said again:
Now that you have accepted me, what do you wish for?
The deer king replied:
If you can regard me with respect, please listen carefully!
I am an animal, I only rely on water and grass to sustain my life, I do not seek anything else.
Great King, you should know that this man was once adrift in the water, with no one to rescue him, his life was almost over. At that time, I was still able to save him;
If you now have a compassionate heart, you should regard this man as you would an infant.

If you look at this man, you are looking at me. This man is foolish, ignorant, and pitiful. After his death, he will surely fall into hell, suffering various hardships for countless years. Therefore, you should give rise to a compassionate heart towards this man.
Great King!
It is like a person with many children, loving them impartially, but feeling a special concern for the sick one;
The bodhisattva is also like this, feeling special compassion and love for evil beings, because these beings harbor evil dharmas.
Therefore, the bodhisattva arouses the mind of enlightenment for the sake of all beings.
At that time, the great king again composed his countenance and said these words:
You are truly a great teacher who tames and guides, upholding the true Dharma, rescuing from danger and distress, a place of refuge, able to remove all fears of beings.
These beings often engage in evil dharmas, their bodies should sink into the earth, but they do not sink, it is certainly because the great being upholds them.
